01 ‚Äì¬†Perceivable1.1 ‚Äì Text AlternativesA1.1.01 Non-Text Content (A):
All non-text content must have a text alternative that serves the same purpose (e.g., alt text for images)		All imagery must have a description available in the code.

This way, people who can't see graphics can still get the information.		Images, icons, illustrations,¬†graphs, charts, decorative elements, ...ü¶æ üëÅÔ∏è

01 ‚Äì¬†Perceivable1.2 ‚Äì Time-based MediaA1.2.01 Audio-only and Video-only (Prerecorded) (A):
Requires alternatives for audio and video content (e.g., transcripts and captions).		When you have a video without sound or a audio file you need to give a text alternative like captions or a transcript.

This way, people who are blind (video) or deaf (audio) can still get the information.		Video-only:
Video without sound, Animation, ...

Audio-Only:
Podcasts, pronounciation guides, ...		üëÇ üëÅÔ∏è

01 ‚Äì¬†Perceivable1.2 ‚Äì Time-based MediaA1.2.02 Captions (Prerecorded) (A):
Requires captions for all prerecorded audio content in synchronized media.		For sound in videos, you have to provide captions as a text alternative.

This way, people who can not listen to the audio can still get the information. This can be useful for deaf users as well as for people who can not listen to sound at the moment (e.g. in public)		Video soundüëÇ
Auditory

Requires audio descriptions for video content.		For video scenery, you have to add a description
of what is visible in the video. You can:

‚Äì describe the scenery in the audio track of the video
or
‚Äì¬†give a text alternative that users can read		VideoüëÇ üëÅÔ∏è

01 ‚Äì¬†Perceivable1.2 ‚Äì Time-based MediaAA1.2.04 Captions (Live) (AA):
Requires captions for live audio content.		For live videos, you have to provide captions as a text alternative.

This way, people who can not listen to the audio can still get the information. This can be useful for deaf users as well as for people who can not listen to sound at the moment (e.g. in public)		Live VideoüëÇ
